The weighted horizontal linear complementarity problem on a Euclidean Jordan algebra

Xiaoni Chi â€ƒâ€ƒ M. Seetharama Gowda â€ƒâ€ƒ Jiyuan Tao
(Received: date / Accepted: date)
Abstract

A weighted complementarity problem (wCP) is to find a pair of vectors belonging to the intersection of a manifold and a cone such that the product of the vectors in a certain algebra equals a given weight vector. If the weight vector is zero, we get a complementarity problem. Examples of such problems include the Fisher market equilibrium problem and the linear programming and weighted centering problem. In this paper we consider the weighted horizontal linear complementarity problem (wHLCP) in the setting of Euclidean Jordan algebras and establish some existence and uniqueness results. For a pair of linear transformations on a Euclidean Jordan algebra, we introduce the concepts of ğ‘0subscriptğ‘0{\bf R}_{0}, ğ‘ğ‘{\bf R}, and ğğ{\bf P} properties and discuss the solvability of wHCLPs under nonzero (topological) degree conditions. A uniqueness result is stated in the setting of â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n}. We show how our results naturally lead to interior point systems.

Keywords:
Weighted horizontal linear complementarity problem Euclidean Jordan algebra Degree ğ‘0subscriptğ‘0{\bf R}_{0}-pair

Our analysis differs from Potraâ€™s potra1 , potra2 in several ways. First, our setting is that of a general Euclidean Jordan algebra, instead of â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n}. Second, instead of the â€˜monotone/sufficientâ€™ conditions, we rely on the ğ‘0subscriptğ‘0{\bf R}_{0} property (that is commonly used in the LCP literature) coupled with a nonzero degree condition of a certain map associated with wHLCP. Third, instead of using the optimization methodology, we rely on the degree theoretic tools. Our analysis also differs from that of Yoshise yoshise where results were proved under certain â€˜monotonicity and injectivityâ€™ conditions.

In this paper, we establish some basic existence/uniqueness results about wHLCPs. Generalizing the LCP concept of a degree of an ğ‘0subscriptğ‘0{\bf R}_{0}-matrix, we introduce the concept of degree of an ğ‘0subscriptğ‘0{\bf R}_{0}-pair of linear transformations in the setting of Euclidean Jordan algebras. Assuming that this degree is nonzero for the pair {A,B}ğ´ğµ\{A,B\}, we show that wHLCP(A,B,w,q)ğ´ğµğ‘¤ğ‘(A,B,w,q) has a nonempty compact solution set for every (w,q)âˆˆV+Ã—V.ğ‘¤ğ‘subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘‰(w,q)\in V_{+}\times V. This conclusion, in particular, will allow us to say that

The organization of our paper is as follows. In Section 2, we cover some basic material. In Section 3, we introduce the concepts of ğ‘0subscriptğ‘0{\bf R}_{0} and ğ‘ğ‘{\bf R} pairs and define the degree of an ğ‘0subscriptğ‘0{\bf R}_{0}-pair. 2.2 A normalization argument

To show that the zero set of a map or a system of equations is bounded, we frequently employ the so-called normalization argument. Here, a certain sequence of vectors (with their norms going to infinity) is normalized to yield a unit vector that violates a given criteria. We illustrate this in the following result, which will be used later.

We remark that such a uniqueness result may not prevail over general Euclidean Jordan algebras even for P-transformations, see the remarks following Theorem 14 in gowda-sznajder-tao .
The above result, especially Item (c)ğ‘(c), allows us to connect ğğ{\bf P}-pairs to the so-called ğ–ğ–{\bf W} property for a pair of matrices, see sznajder-gowda .

Concluding Remarks. In this paper, we have presented some existence and uniqueness results for weighted horizontal linear complementarity problems over Euclidean Jordan algebras. These are established for ğ‘0subscriptğ‘0{\bf R}_{0}-pairs of linear transformations satisfying a (nonzero) degree condition. The novelty here is the use of â€˜weightedâ€™ Fischer-Burmeister map and degree theory techniques. We hope to consider applications, algorithms, and non ğ‘0subscriptğ‘0{\bf R}_{0}-pairs in a future study.
